verses.verse: (2 Elihu reproveth them of folly.8 Age maketh not a man wise, but the spirit of God.) So these three men ceased to answer Job, because he (Hebrew, was just in his own eyes.) esteemed himself just.

Then the wrath of Elihu the son of Barachel the (Which came of Buz, the son of Nahor, Abraham’s brother.) Buzite, of the family of (Or, as the Chaldean paraphrase readeth, Abram.) Ram, was kindled: his wrath, I say, was kindled against Job, because he justified himself (By making himself innocent, and by charging God of rigor.) more than God.
Also his anger was kindled against his three friends, because they could not find an answer, and yet condemned Job.
(Now Elihu had waited till Job had spoken: for (That is, the three mentioned before.) they were more ancient in years than he.)
So when Elihu saw, that there was none answer in the mouth of the three men, his wrath was kindled.
Therefore Elihu the son of Barachel, the Buzite answered and said, I am young in years, and ye are ancient: therefore I doubted, and was afraid to show you mine opinion.
For I said, The days (Meaning, the ancient, which have experience.) shall speak, and the multitude of years shall teach wisdom.
Surely there is a spirit in man, (It is a special gift of God that man hath understanding, and cometh neither of nature nor by age.) but the inspiration of the Almighty giveth understanding.
Great men are not always wise, neither do the aged always understand judgment.
Therefore I say, Hear me and I will show also mine opinion.
Behold, I did wait upon your words, and hearkened unto your knowledge, while you sought out (To prove that Job’s affliction came for his sins.) reasons.
Yea, when I had considered you, lo, there was none of you that reproved Job, nor answered his words:
Lest ye should say, We have (And flatter yourselves, as though you had overcome him.) found wisdom: for God hath cast him down, and no man.
Yet hath (To wit, Job.) he not directed his words to me, neither will I answer (He useth almost the like arguments, but without taunting and reproaches.) him by your words.
Then they fearing, answered no more, but left off their talk.
When I had waited (for they spake not, but stood still and answered no more)
Then answered I in my turn, and I showed mine opinion.
For I am full of (I have conceived in my mind great store of reasons.) matter, and the spirit within me compelleth me.
Behold, my belly is as the wine, which hath no vent, and like the new bottles that burst.
Therefore will I speak, that I may take breath: I will open my lips, and will answer.
I will not now accept the person of man, (I will neither have regard to riches, credit, nor authority, but will speak the very truth.) neither will I give titles to man.

For I may not give (The Hebrew word signifieth, to change the name, as to call a fool a wise man: meaning, that he would not cloak the truth to flatter men.) titles, lest my Maker should take me away suddenly.
